thread.title: Coaches crack down on high school football hazing
thread.title_full: Coaches crack down on high school football hazing | Boston Herald

author: Bob McGovern , Brian Dowling
title: Coaches crack down on high school football hazing
text:
Hazing accusations have forced two Bay State high school football teams to forfeit games already this season, prompting coaches to warn their squads to shun bullying or risk being the next gridiron squad forced to sit on the sidelines.
“My boys know that if they do it, they’re off the team immediately,” said Bill Maradei, head coach of the Austin Prep football team. “I’m going to address my team about this. We usually talk football, but we want to make sure that they’re living the right way and doing the right thing.”
Winthrop High School will not practice this week and will forfeit its game against Gloucester tomorrow after police announced they are investigating a locker-room video being circulated that shows a football player changing.
Swampscott High School also forfeited games earlier this month after officials said the football team had five teammates perform exercises and athletic drills naked in the center of the school’s football field. Swampscott forfeited a freshman game and a varsity game against Saugus High School.
“We talk about it all the time. We talk about hazing and bullying and how it’s not acceptable. It’s not part of athletics, and it’s not part of society,” said Duane Sigsbury, head football coach at Billerica High School. “Every time something does happen in the news, we go over it with them. They have to be responsible in the community, the field and the locker rooms.”
Winthrop police Chief Terence M. Delehanty said police are speaking with at least 10 students and their parents about the video. Though a student said the video was sent through a group text message, Delehanty would not comment on how widely it was distributed.
Delehanty declined to go into detail about the case and also would not say whether the student who was taped knew the video was being made.
Hazing is considered a crime under Massachusetts law, but it is a difficult problem to put a stop to, according to Dr. Susan Lipkins, a psychologist who has studied the problem. She said hazing is passed down from generation to generation as a type of rite of passage. There is also a “code of silence” that prevents teens from ratting on each other, Lipkins said.
She said canceling games is common but it doesn’t solve the underlying problem.
“I think that it gets everyone in the community aware of what’s going on, and maybe other communities look and think, ‘We don’t want that happening to us,’ ” Lipkins said. “But adolescents believe that they have a special coding. They don’t think it’s going to happen to them — they think it’s going to happen to everyone else.”
Winthrop Superintendent John J. Macero said the incident was a blow to the school’s reputation.
“When anything like this happens it gives you a black eye on our programs, and we don’t like that at all because it’s a representation of Winthrop Public Schools,” he said.
Macero said he believes the video was taken Monday evening in the boys locker room.
Police said they are working with the Suffolk District Attorney’s Office to determine if any charges will be filed.
Macero added students need to set limits on using their smartphones, adding: “Today in the world with phones and social media, they just send things around and they don’t understand — unlike us who didn’t have that social media when we were younger.”
